p: Recently, several studies have reported the antinociceptive activity of Thymus sp. extracts and their major constituents (Mahmoudi et al. 2011; Taherian et al. 2009; Cavalcante Melo et al. 2012). In this way, we evaluated whether T. capitatus EO also induces analgesy in vivo. For that, the glutamate-induced nociception model was performed in mice pretreated with T. capitatus EO by the oral tract, in order to imply that the drug was absorbed in vivo. Our data demonstrated significant analgesic activity and dose-dependency of T. capitatus EO ( Figure 1).
